bibl.title: Letter from M.J. Rosenau to Henry Rose Carter, December 3, 1924

div1.p: Rosenau informs Carter that he has no knowledge of plague on ships.

div1.head: Letter from M.J. Rosenau to Henry Rose Carter, December 3, 1924
div1.opener:
Book
Plague
HARVARD UNIVERSITY
MEDICAL SCHOOL
DEPARTMENT OF PREVENTIVE MEDICINE AND HYGIENE
Boston, Massachusetts.
December 3, 1924.
Dr. H. R. Carter,
2122 California Street, N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
I have no satisfactory knowledge that would
be of use to you concerning plague on ships. It seems to me
highly improbable under present conditions that there could
be an epidemic of bubonic plague on regular liners or even
tramp steamers using measures to keep the rat population down.
It is conceivable that in boats overrun with rats, especially
in the old days on wooden boats, there might have been epidem-
ics and epizootics on shipboard. From our knowledge of the
epidemiology of la peste, it seems to me unlikely that this
would happen often. Epidemics of pneumonic plague might well
break out on shipboard, given a primary case of the pneumonic
form of the disease. Of this, however, I have neither record
nor reference. I should think somebody at the Bureau would
have the literature and the facts well at hand, particularly
in the Quarantine Division. You have aroused my interest, and
if you get anything satisfactory, would you be good enough to
let me know?
